gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: audio_codec.

Explanation: The "audio_codec" module is a design for audio data processing, specifically designed to interface with an audio codec. This module handles the synchronization of the Audio Bit Clock, Left/Right Clock and data for audio input (ADC) and output (DAC). This makes it possible to read and write audio data from and to the audio codec. The module contains two primary tasks regards to audio read and write:

1. Audio Read: It uses an audio deserializer to convert the incoming serial audio data stream to parallel data for both left and right audio channels. The readiness of the data to be read is indicated by signals "read_ready", "readdata_left", and "readdata_right".

2. Audio Write: It uses an audio serializer to convert parallel audio data to a serial stream for both left and right channels. The readiness of the system to accept data for writing is indicated by the "write_ready" signal. Consequently, the processed data is outputted via "AUD_DACDAT". This module uses the de-facto data width standard of 24 bits for audio data.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input Ports:

1. CLOCK_50 (input): This is the system clock signal that controls the timing of the module.
2. reset (input): This signal is used to reset the state of the module.
3. read_s (input): This signal indicates the readiness to read audio data.
4. write_s (input): This signal indicates the readiness to write audio data.
5. writedata_left and writedata_right (inputs): These are 24-bit data streams for the left and right audio channels respectively that need to be written.
6. AUD_ADCDAT (input): This is the input audio data stream coming from the ADC (Analog to Digital Converter).
7. AUD_BCLK (input): This is the audio bit clock signal.
8. AUD_ADCLRCK (input): This is the left/right clock signal for the ADC.
9. AUD_DACLRCK (input): This is the left/right clock signal for the DAC (Digital to Analog Converter).

Output Ports:

1. read_ready and write_ready (outputs): These signals indicate whether the system is ready to read and write audio data respectively.
2. readdata_left and readdata_right (outputs): These are 24-bit outputs for left and right audio channel data that have been read.
3. AUD_DACDAT (output): This is the output audio data stream to be sent to the DAC.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
Internal signals: 
1. bclk_rising_edge
2. bclk_falling_edge
3. adc_lrclk_rising_edge
4. adc_lrclk_falling_edge
5. new_left_channel_audio
6. new_right_channel_audio
7. left_channel_read_available
8. right_channel_read_available
9. dac_lrclk_rising_edge
10. dac_lrclk_falling_edge
11. left_channel_write_space
12. right_channel_write_space
13. done_adc_channel_sync
14. done_dac_channel_sync

Explanation:
1. bclk_rising_edge: This signal detects the rising edge of the audio bit clock (AUD_BCLK).
2. bclk_falling_edge: This signal detects the falling edge of the audio bit clock (AUD_BCLK).
3. adc_lrclk_rising_edge: This signal detects the rising edge of the ADC left/right clock (AUD_ADCLRCK).
4. adc_lrclk_falling_edge: This signal detects the falling edge of the ADC left/right clock (AUD_ADCLRCK).
5. new_left_channel_audio: This wire array holds the newly deserialized audio data for the left channel.
6. new_right_channel_audio: This wire array holds the newly deserialized audio data for the right channel.
7. left_channel_read_available: This signal indicates if there are any audio data available on the left channel to be read.
8. right_channel_read_available: This signal indicates if there are any audio data available on the right channel to be read.
9. dac_lrclk_rising_edge: This signal detects the rising edge of the DAC left/right clock (AUD_DACLRCK).
10. dac_lrclk_falling_edge: This signal detects the falling edge of the DAC left/right clock (AUD_DACLRCK).
11. left_channel_write_space: This signal indicates if there is free space for writing audio data on the left channel.
12. right_channel_write_space: This signal indicates if there is free space for writing audio data on the right channel.
13. done_adc_channel_sync: This register keeps the sync status of the ADC left/right clock.
14. done_dac_channel_sync: This register keeps the sync status of the DAC left/right clock.
